Vertical Gardening: If the ground becomes too hard to dig into, one can opt for vertical gardening. This method involves growing plants in containers or vertically on walls or fences. This approach allows for more efficient use of space and can be done without digging into the ground.

Raised Beds: Another option is to create raised beds on top of the hard ground. This can be done by building wooden or metal frames and filling them with soil. This approach allows for easier planting and maintenance of the garden, as well as better drainage.

Hydroponics: Hydroponics is a method of growing plants without soil. Instead, the plants are grown in a nutrient-rich solution that is free of contaminants. This method is ideal for areas with hard ground, as it does not require any digging or soil preparation.

Aquaponics: Aquaponics is a method of growing plants using fish waste as a nutrient source. This method involves setting up a system where fish are raised in a tank and their waste is used to fertilize plants grown in a separate container. This approach is ideal for areas with hard ground, as it does not require any digging or soil preparation.

Permaculture: Permaculture is a method of sustainable agriculture that involves using natural systems to grow plants. This approach involves designing a garden to mimic natural ecosystems, with plants and other organisms working together to create a self-sustaining system. This approach can be used in areas with hard ground, as it does not require any digging or soil preparation.
